message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results suggest Down syndrome, and the ultrasound finding of increased nuchal translucency is also associated with Down syndrome. Common characteristics of newborns with Down syndrome include epicanthal folds, macroglossia, flat profile, depressed nasal bridge, and simian palmar crease. Option A describes characteristics of Cri-du-chat syndrome, option B describes characteristics of Trisomy 13, and option D describes characteristics of Williams syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated inhibin and beta HCG, decreased aFP and estriol, and increased nuchal translucency are all indicative of Down syndrome. The characteristics described in option (C) are commonly seen in newborns with Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results suggest Down syndrome, and the increased nuchal translucency seen on ultrasound is a common feature of Down syndrome. Option C describes characteristics commonly seen in infants with Down syndrome, such as epicanthal folds, flat profile, and simian palmar crease. Option A describes characteristics commonly seen in infants with cri-du-chat syndrome, Option B describes characteristics commonly seen in infants with Trisomy 13, and Option D describes characteristics commonly seen in infants with Williams syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results and increased nuchal translucency suggest Down syndrome, and among the options, only (C) describes the characteristics consistent with Down syndrome such as epicanthal folds, macroglossia, and a depressed nasal bridge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results, including increased inhibin and beta HCG and decreased aFP and estriol, suggest Down syndrome. An increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound is also a marker for Down syndrome. Common characteristics of infants with Down syndrome may include epicanthal folds, macroglossia, flat profile, depressed nasal bridge, and simian palmar crease. Options A and D are associated with other genetic syndromes, and option B includes features that are not commonly seen in Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is incorrect because it describes characteristics of cri-du-chat syndrome. Option B describes characteristics of trisomy 13. Option D is incorrect because it describes characteristics of Williams syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results and increased nuchal translucency suggest a high risk for Down syndrome. Common characteristics of newborns with Down syndrome include epicanthal folds, macroglossia, flat profile, depressed nasal bridge, and simian palmar crease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormal quad screen and increased nuchal translucency suggest Down syndrome. The characteristics listed in option (C) are typical physical features of Down syndrome, including epicanthal folds, macroglossia, flat profile, depressed nasal bridge, and simian palmar crease. Option (A) describes characteristics of cri-du-chat syndrome, option (B) describes characteristics of Patau syndrome, and option (D) describes characteristics of Williams syndrome, which are not suggested by the quad screen and increased nuchal translucency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated inhibin and beta HCG, decreased aFP and estriol, and increased nuchal translucency suggest Down syndrome, with the most common physical characteristics being epicanthal folds, macroglossia, flat profile, depressed nasal bridge, and simian palmar crease. Option A describes characteristics of cri-du-chat syndrome, Option B describes characteristics of Patau syndrome, and Option D describes characteristics of Williams syndrome, none of which match the quad screen results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The quad screen results suggest Down syndrome, and increased nuchal translucency also suggests Down syndrome. Option C describes the physical characteristics commonly associated with Down syndrome, including epicanthal folds and simian palmar crease. Option A describes characteristics of cri-du-chat syndrome, option B describes characteristics of various syndromes including Patau syndrome and option D describes characteristics of Williams syndrome.
